contentrichtext.text: In [[genetics]], '''dyad symmetry''' refers to two areas of a [[DNA]] strand whose base pair sequences are [[inverted repeat]]s of each other. They are often described as [[palindromes]]. For example, the following shows dyad symmetry between sequences GAATAC and GTATTC which are reverse complements of each other. <source lang="text">...GAATAC...CTG...GTATTC...</source> ==Involvement in transcription== Since the two reverse complementary sequences will fold and base-pair with each other, the sequence of bases between them form a [[hairpin loop]]. This structure is thought to destabilize the binding of RNA polymerase enzyme to DNA (hence terminating transcription). Dyad symmetry is known to have a role in the rho independent method of transcription termination in E. coli. {{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Regions of dyad symmetry in the DNA sequence stall the RNA polymerase enzyme as it transcribes them. ==Involvement in prophage integration== Temperate [[bacteriophage]]s integrate into the host genome at specific interrupted dyad symmetry sequences using the phage encoded enzyme integrase (see [[Lambda_phage#Prophage_integration|prophage integration]]).<ref name="Bacteriophages">Richard Calendar (2006) ''The Bacteriophages'' (Oxford University Press, Oxford, NY) ISBN 0-19-514850-9, page 67</ref> == External links == * [http://www.biology-online.org/dictionary/Dyad_symmetry_of_dna Definition] at Biology Online {{Reflist}} [[Category:Molecular genetics]] {{genetics-stub}}
